content: While the plot holes are slightly-annoying, this is on-par with Spirited Away for me.Where it lacks, it is made up for in visuals and worldbuilding.Both of which are some of the best I have ever seen in an animated film.As implied: if you can look past the inconsistencies, you are in for a treat.

title: The template for all future Studio Ghibli masterpieces!
content: Made in 1984, this is the movie which set Studio Ghibli in motion and has all the hall marks of the studios future fantasy outings!"Bad Guys" who use clunky, industrial, mechanical devices, "Good Guys", who are in tune with nature and have genuine empathy for wildlife and their people. A strong female lead, often a Princess on a quest, preferring to use peace rather than violence to solve a mystery / problem.There is an almost steampunk feel about this film, with swords and armour sitting comfortably against tanks, magic and mythical creatures, but it is delivered in a really colourful, wholesome, and heart warming way.Studio Ghibli movies are well known and loved but it's great to see where it all started!

title: The best Studio Ghibli film to ever exist
content: Nausicaa was certainly the best Ghibli film I've seen to date, I think the mix of action and suspense through the movie all while Nausicaa is emphasizing peace certainly makes the whole aspect of this film very unique. The resolution (spoiler-free) definitely made me tear up I can admit, however, I was extremely satisfied with how it ended. Overall I believe this is a 10/10 film and a must watch for any Japanese Animation, Studio Ghibli, or suspense fan.Also, Princess Nausicaa is better than any Disney princess.

title: Suitable for both children and adults.
content: The first thing to establish is that this is an epic science-fiction novel. Given this, one's expectations should be adjusted somewhat; ultimately, the film's high grade may be credited to its science-fiction components. It was a terrific science fiction plot, but it didn't make me feel anything, which is what I want from an animated film. The protagonist of the futuristic science fiction book "Nausicaa" is a princess/warrior/nature lover with strong environmental concerns. An adversarial princess or leader is also there, and she is using devices to prevail over what seems to be a hostile environment.Nausicaa doesn't have many shortcomings; the animation isn't as good as it has been in other Ghibli films, and the settings aren't as lovely, but they are more than enough.One of the film's great qualities is its rapid pace. What truly distinguishes this work is the incredible attention to detail in the post-apocalyptic science fiction and fantasy world that serves as the story's backdrop, as well as the sophisticated but not overly complicated storytelling, the enthralling background drawings and settings, and, most importantly, the incredible attention to detail in the fully realised world. Everything is so well thought out and performed that you find yourself appreciating things that aren't even the major subject of the film but rather serve as backdrops. "Nausicaa" had been around for a long time as a serialised manga, so Miyazaki was probably familiar with the setting.There's a clever story at work here about humanity's role in the natural world, but I won't give anything away.It's the kind of film that can captivate an audience from start to finish and stands up well over several viewings. To be honest, this film is suitable for both children and adults. Even if that isn't the case, many consider Miyazaki's second film to be the start of Studio Ghibli since it is his second feature. Perhaps the historical importance of the incident makes it worthwhile to witness.

title: Childhood favorite, still a great movie
content: I used to watch the American version of this movie all the time as a child and recently got to see the full Japanese version.  I loved the full version even more.  It's entertaining enough to capture the short attention span of a child, and interesting enough to continue to do so with adults.  If you like anime watch this movie.

title: No words for Creativity...
content: Fantastic movie with great fantasy story told with animation in 1980s. Nature always finds a way.

title: The birth of a legend
content: Hayao Miyazaki has established himself as a pioneer in the animation market world wide, giving us beautifully animated, life full and emotional narratives in his own distinct style.And this is the one that started it all. (He had previously directed one other animated feature, though nowhere near where he would later go in both scope and vision, and it was mostly a sequel in a series) Telling an interesting fantasy tale with a compelling lead, it goes beyond what has been done before, both in anime and in western animation.So much is owed to this film, and it's only the start of an amazing career!

title: One of Ghibli's finest films
content: A wonderfully and important story, told expertly and animated gorgeously. The incredible "blanks" the viewer must fill while watching are just incredible. The way Miyazaki keeps the viewer actively imagining and explore your imagination.I love how Miyazaki builds this world; it has the unique Ghibli brand painted all over it. A gorgeous and fitting soundtrack from master composer Joe Hisaishi brings the package together incredibly well.There are only a couple of niggling issues keeping it from perfection, like some simple writing and disjointed events. An impressive classic featuring some of the most beautiful hand drawn animation ever.

title: Film not for young children under 9 or 10
content: This is an excellent piece of Japanese animation, and we own several other movies of the same genre. However, the battle scenes were a bit graphic for our 8-year old daughter. She enjoyed the first half, where she's learning about the warrior princess who will defend her valley no matter what. The last third of the movie contains the violence. Maybe I'm just protective but I think there is enough violence in most teen and adult movies, and I would rather not expose my child to it while she's young. In the last part of this film, the princess is attacked and shot with a machine gun. She is bleeding from wounds in her shoulder and foot and moaning in pain on the ground. Shortly after this, she is accidentally pushed into an acid lake, where she screams in agony as her foot is burned by chemicals. I thought that entire scene was well done, realistic, and graphic, but it is NOT for the eyes of a young child.

title: Amazing
content: This is a fantastic, world-building, astounding film. It looks fantastic, and the story is equally great. Love this movie!

title: (9.5/10) A masterpiece from Hayao Miyazaki
content: Nausicaa of the Valley of the Wind is a breathtaking, engaging film with an amazing soundtrack and fantastic animation. For Miyazaki's second film, he truly outdid himself on this one. The tone is darker than some of Ghibli's other works like My Neighbour Totoro and Kiki's Delivery Service but there's still some lighthearted moments speckled throughout the movie. Definitely Ghibli's second best film and a true masterpiece.

title: I preferred the comic
content: Though seen as a classic by many anime-lovers, it doesn't even come close to the original comic. It seems that the director (the artist and writer of the graphic novel) gave up the idea of making a perfect adaption of his non-animated work after the first ten minutes of the film. Don't get me wrong, it's a good movie, but about as disappointing as the animated version of the Lord of the Rings, stopping right in the middle of the story as well. Viewers of the German translation beware: Many scenes were cut (and dialogue rewritten) in this version, as the translaters didn't like the idea of this film actually critisizing industrial pollution ! Not necessarily a must see. You be the judge.

title: great movie,great animation,great music

title: Fantastic
content: Has the heart of every studio Ghibli movie after it, with even more. Amazing world building and characters.Movie is a bit slow not for younger veiwers will probably get bored but if your above the age of 10 you should thouroughly enjoy this movie

title: Simple yet beautiful...
content: Wow this movie really turnt up at the end. The dialogue was well done between the characters. The visuals and the music were amazing considering its time when it first came out, the music especially was really nice. The fight scenes were also nice they felt fluid and natural and not stiff and unrealistic. The pacing/plot was ok, the beginning and the end were the best for me, the middle I felt like it dragged a bit too long, and the overall story was ok but I think it definitely had a higher potential if they made the world more open and realistic.The true spotlight of this movies lies in its themes such as friendship, sacrifice, and human destruction. Those themes were very well presented and shown to the audience. But with the themes I think they sacrificed some other things such as the pacing, plot and characters.I enjoyed the movie but this wasn't exactly my type of movie that I would enjoy very much maybe for other people it would have been better. If your a person that simply can ignore the slight mistakes of the story and pacing and simply seek to the know the themes and meaning of a movie or show this is a must watch.Memorable: No Rewatchable: No.

title: Moody, dramatic and superb!
content: I saw this movie the first time for more than ten years ago, only half of it of course and without sound. Yet I was stunned. The visions in the movie were different from anything I had ever seen before that time and I wanted to know more. Over the years I almost forgot I had seen the movie, but the name lingered in my head. Yesterday, I got my hands on it again and what can I say, it surpassed my wildest dreams of that movie in a heartbeat. Great landscapes, great drama, exciting story!See this movie. I do recommend it.

title: A persuasive prediction
content: Opposing many current animations with much computer graphics, this monumental animation film of Miyazaki shows us the infinite possibility of Japanese animation as the way of embodying imagination. This film seems lifelike without using CG and the elaborate story line makes the film all the more realistic and persuasive.The story is set in the future where humans are living afraid of the poisonous jungle and monsters. People try to burn out the jungle with using 'Kyoshinhei'(a man-made robot that has mass destructive power). People are fighting each other to get this robot that can be a big help of humans or a destructive weapon at the same time. But in fact, the poisonous jungle is purifying the land which humans have polluted and monsters are guarding the jungle from destruction. Therefore, they cannot survive by burning the poisonous jungle. Nausicaa, as a sacrifice, lets us know that what people are doing is completely wrong and they should not destroy Nature any more.I guess this is a prediction of our future. If we kept polluting the land, the world would be like this. We cannot recover polluted land by eliminating them. I think some films of Miyazaki are based on this idea that humans are considered as a part of Nature and we are supposed to coexist with Nature. This story casts the doubt that we are killing ourselves now.

title: A beautiful story destroyed by the infidel Americans...
content: Originally under the name of Naushca (Something) no Kaze.  This story takes place in a post apocalyptic world that is now over run by huge hulking insects and mold that is slowly devouring the world.  The story revolves around a girl who is kind to animals.  She uses technology that somehow relates to the power of wind.  Although the description of the movie right now seems more like a horror movie than a science fiction, it isn't.  As typical with the collection this movie comes from it is an uplifting love story that will touch your heart and bring you back to your days of passionate youth.  I would suggest this movies to youth although after seeing this they might go and try to end world violence.  But really folks...it's a good movie with a fulfilling the unfillable prophecy role that Japan is oh so famous for and this one has no excessive violence or sex.

title: Not as Hayao intended
content: Whilst agreeing with the front page comment on this film, pitched against the comic I must say that this is a very important film in its own right. Being 'butchered' for the western market (not just the Germans!) and being targeted towards children, did not help its cause.The version currently available is the same as originally released and lord knows who the characters are on the front of the case!! By the way, the dub is terrible.My advice is to wait for an official release, either by Studio Ghibli or the Disney/Tokuma partnership and see the real thing as the Director intended.Let us not forget that it was it was the decimation of this film which nearly turned Miyazaki against ever releasing any of his films in the West.Having said that, there is much to enjoy in the animation of this release but you will have to wait for the original to get the full story.

title: Impressive
content: This film is definitely builds on the reputation of anime as being the most creative and worthy of the animation genre. Back in '84 it must have posed extremely high standards for what was to come after it.All that we expect from an excellent anime is here: it's very emotonal and humane, there are some great battle scenes, and the story is a product of a very wild and unrestrained imagination. Totally recommended for everyone. This is what great animation is about.

title: Great first half, weaker ending; See Mononoke first
content: In agreement with many other reviewers I would comment that this movie has excellent moments, interesting characters and a truly fascinating world reminiscent of Dune (but far better than any of the awful movie adaptations of that). I wish some of the relationships and nations had been more fleshed out (they are in the manga), but I was fascinated by the themes he explores and the architecture and nature he invents are intriguing as always!However, as Miyazaki himself has pointed out, this movie was made before the comic was finished, leading to an inferior and partly rushed ending which Miyazaki himself did not like. It is far from a bad movie, but I would highly recommend watching Spirited Away and Princess Mononoke (which has a similar theme) before. Watch Nausicaa after if you want to explore some of his earlier work, it's enjoyable as long as you don't expect perfection.

title: Nausicaä: Reviewed
content: A thoroughly typical Studio Ghibli movie, which means that it's charmingly and expertly animated, and has an environmentally friendly message.I can't place Nausicaä among my favorite Ghibli films like Spirited Away and The Cat Returns, though. Other than Nausicaä herself, the characters aren't very memorable. The story is simple and straightforward, almost to the point of being bland, and the pro-nature message is very heavy-handed, even though it's appreciated. The first half of the movie is also better than the latter half, in my opinion.Still, this is a movie I like to revisit from time to time, even though it lacks some of the imagination and immersion of superior Ghibli films. It's beautifully animated, though in a way that's more utilitarian than awe-inducing. Keep in mind, that even a merely "decent" Ghibli film is still more than worth checking out.

title: Worth every penny to see
content: I viewed the (Subtitled version) Do not work yourself up about the fuss of whether or not Nausika was wearing undergarments. I was too engaged with the momentum of the unfolding story in which to really care about such matters.To be simple and blunt I felt uplifted.Sometimes it is good to let go of the "I'm a smart rationalist movie reviewer mode and not seek fault for faults sake.Miyazaki for me is a fine "composer" of movies I use the word composer due to my feeling that this man has an understanding of how to communicate to me from a meta-biological level akin to Mozart and Beethoven.

title: Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind
content: I worked for the producer who imported many Japanese anime, and I'm not sure, but this may have been one of them. The Americanized version is shorter, has the usual poor dubbing, and truncates a lot of the nuances of the story's meanings that otherwise come through with the additional footage of the original film.I purchased a special edition DVD when it first came out. Wow. A massive box with lots of extras, and all for a movie. I didn't mind. I also purchased the Disney publication of the same film, and watch that disk as opposed to the disk that came with a scale model of one of the critters of the film, a pouch duplicating the princesses, and a few other do-dads that I can't recall right now. It wasn't cheap, but at the time I had the money.But, to the movie. It's excellent. Good stuff which shows Miyazaki's outlook on the natural order of things, and how there's no real evil in the world, just hurt souls waiting to be healed and rediscovered, or parties operating at odds with one another. That's his point of view, or POV as we say in the film bizz.The animation, like all Japanese animation, is somewhat stilted at times, and some of the perspective shots are a little exaggerated or stiff, but the story and overall film making remain strong. This is an early epic sci-fi anime film that shows a female heroine overcoming challenges with charm, wit and strength, forming a holy trinity of a dynamic soul that has the hearts and minds of all involved in a warmonger's quest to resurrect an awful truth from the past.As with all things Japanese there're subtle themes being played here. The visuals are delightful, and can either be watched with a family or enjoyed as a solo effort.Truly a great piece of anime, and truly a great film unto itself. Go check out a copy and enjoy.

title: not the original film!  don't judge this one
content: This horribly mangled version of Kaze no Tani no Naushika (Nausicaa of the Valley of the Wind) released in Germany, France, and the United States was completely edited, and ruined.  Hayao Miyazaki had absolutely nothing to do with the Warriors of the Wind, or whatever it was lamely titled.  He, and his team of animators, said to dismiss it from mind.  The real wonderfully animated and written version, is completely different, and much better. The cover of the movie is also more attractive, as opposed to this one...The only way to really see Nausicaa is to buy the imported and subtitled version from Japan.  Or buy the manga...
